üåü What is SAP Inside Track?

For those new to it, SAP Inside Track (SIT) is a community-driven event where SAP professionals, experts, and enthusiasts come together to:

It‚Äôs an event for the community, by the community, and Pune has already shown how vibrant and powerful this community can be.

We will dive deep into how AI is transforming business processes and user experiences across:

entry.title: Re: How to Deploy/Publish RAP & Annotation based UI List...
entry.content:
Hello @G_Sachin,

Thank you for your question,

Below is the verified Public Cloud pathway with clickable links:

What you should do

Expose your data as a UI service
In ADT: CDS ‚Üí Service Definition ‚Üí Service Binding (OData V4 ‚Äì UI) and activate. SAP Help Portal-Defining and Publishing a UI Service

Generate the Fiori Elements app and deploy it
Use SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) ‚Üí Fiori: List Report/Object Page‚Üí point to your OData V4 service binding URL ‚Üí Deploy to ABAP your S/4HANA Cloud system. This also creates the FLP app descriptor. SAP-Create a SAP Fiori App and Deploy it to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment
(VS Code isn‚Äôt the supported path for S/4HANA Cloud customers; BAS is the documented route.)

Make it visible to users

Create an IAM App and Business Catalogue -Creating Business Catalogues or add the app to an existing catalogue. SAP Help Portal-Creating an IAM App and Adding It to a Business Catalogue

Alternatively, use Custom Catalogue Extensions to place the app in a catalogue without creating a new one. SAP Help Portal-Custom Catalogue Extensions

In Manage Launchpad Spaces/Pages, add the app as a tile for the role; then assign the role to users. SAP Help Portal-Managing Launchpad Spaces and Pages

Reasons why your Eclipse Preview might not show up as a tile.
The ADT preview is currently in developer preview. A tile appears after deployment and once catalogue or space assignment is completed.

Useful SAP Documentation References

ABAP RAP: Defining and publishing a UI service (Service Binding). SAP Help Portal-Defining and Publishing a UI Service

Tutorial: Create a Fiori application using BAS and deploy it to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP environment. (Includes steps for IAM app and catalogue). SAP-Create a SAP Fiori App and Deploy it to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment

Manage Launchpad Spaces/Pages ‚Äì add an app tile for a specific role. SAP Help Portal

Feel free to reachout.

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Trouble Shooting for CDS Views
entry.content:
in the following expression that is used like shown in a productive environment, ep.netwr (ep is alias for ekpo) should be devided by rbkp-kursf to have the value returned in the appropriate currency 

      case

        when curr_to_decfloat_amount(r.Wrbtr) > 0 then r.Wrbtr

                                                  else ep.netwr

      end as Wrbtr,  

 

 

to make things easier I build a separate small view only to do this:

define view entity ZRPR_C_GET_EKPO_NETWR_WITH_REF as select from ekpo as ep

  inner join ekko as e on ep.ebeln = e.ebeln

  inner join rseg as r on  ep.ebeln = r.ebeln

                       and ep.ebelp = r.ebelp

  inner join rbkp as rb on ep.ebeln = r.ebeln

{

  key ep.ebeln,

  key ep.ebelp,

  e.waers as ekko_waers,

  rb.kursf,

  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'ekko_waers'

  ep.netwr / rb.kursf as netwr

}

NETWR is a field in table EKPO and the reference field f√ºr the CURR field is a field in Table EKKO, for this reason the annotation refers to ekko_waers

coded like above the error occurs "Datatype CURR is not supported here", that means I have to use either get_numeric_value( ep.netwr )

or curr_to_decfloat_amount( ep.netwr )  In both cases the annotation is ignored  and trying to activate generates the error in SM21 in SAP: invalid column name EP-WAERS while following the annotation the system should not look for the reference field in table EKPO, because the annotation directs to look for in in table EKKO. Why is the annotation ignored one using curr_to_decfloat_amount or get_numeric_value? What to do, to solve this?

entry.title: Re: How to batch print journal entries in Manage Journal...
entry.content:
Hello @jason_su 

The S4HANA Public Cloud, Manage Journal Entries (F0717A) does not support mass print; Creating correspondence in that app is restricted to a single document (hence the button is disabled when multiple items are selected). To print several vouchers, use the Create Correspondence (F0744A). Open the app, upload the documents, and the output will be managed for each item or list you keep in that app. Note that Print Correspondence (F2801) is FI-CA, not FI-GL, so it won‚Äôt be useful for journal vouchers.  

SAP Help Portal-Create Correspondence

If true batch output is required, the workaround is a small custom app or process that loops through the document numbers and triggers correspondence one by one.

With kind regards
Chuma

entry.title: Re: Change payee name for 1 vendor
entry.content:
Please note if the Payee field (LFA1-ZAHLS) is filled, SAP will use that name instead of Name 1. So check in vendor master, how it is filled. Next go to FBZP, and check whether the payee name is pulled from vendor master or overridden. Some configurations allow for alternate payee logic.

For information, from vendor master ‚Üí Payment Transactions, check:

  • Alternate Payee in Document (LFA1-ZAHLS)
  • Alternate Payee in Master Record (LFB1-ZAHLS)

If these are filled, SAP will use the alternate payee name instead of the vendor‚Äôs Name 1.

Also, since your issue is on the output, check the SmartForm which may pull name from Vendor master, Payment document or Alternate payee. Confirm which field is used in the layout logic

Hello everyone,
In the industrial planning process, in Controlling, we want to obtain product cost estimates. To obtain the cost estimate, we need to calculate the rates for the activities involved in the process.

entry.title: Re: Trial balance and General ledger balance of Sundry cr...
entry.content:
Hi,

With limited information it is not possible to determine anything specific which could relate to the issue.

The generic things which you can check is below:

1.  Go to Administration Module > System Initialization > General Settings > BP tab.  Select the checkbox 'Display Inactive Business Partners in Reports' and then run the report.

2. If you are running the reports for a backdate, then you need to make sure that you need to have 'Display Customers/Suppliers with zero amount' in the Aging Report checkbox.

If this does not help, then re-visit your setup/filters in both the Trial Balance and General Ledger including the Expanded Selection criteria.

Kr,

Jitin

entry.title: Re: "Could Not Open App" Error in SAP Mobile Start Androi...
entry.content:
Hi @Chris1973,

You are correct for custom apps; you can manually define the semanticObject and action in the Work Zone content configuration. But as you mentioned in your case, the My Inbox app is coming from a Remote Content Provider which is SAP S/4HANA Cloud. To resolve this, consider the following evaluations.

  1. Go to In Work Zone √† Channel Manager, review your S/4HANA Cloud remote content provider. Ensure that My Inbox is correctly subscribed and synchronized.
  2. In your S/4HANA Cloud system, check the App Finder or Maintain Business Roles. Confirm that the My Inbox app has a defined semanticObject/action which is usually ‚ÄúWorkflowTask-manage‚Äù. If it is missing, raise an SAP incident under Component CA-FLP-FIO-AIC App Integration Catalog.
  3. After adjusting roles or checking in S/4, go back to Work Zone Content Manager and refresh the remote content provider. This pulls the correct metadata including the semanticObject/action.
  4. In Work Zone, ensure the imported My Inbox app is marked as Mobile Enabled. Then re-publish the site and clear the Mobile Start cache.

Consult these links for further details.

Configuring Target Mappings

Configure the My Inbox App

SAP Mobile Start - Troubleshooting

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Advanced formula code - Request for Help: Understandi...
entry.content:
Hi @praveen_kumar334 

From a technical perspective, your advanced formulas script generates two temporary tables for the VariableMember.

One table is VariableMember #Date, while the other is VariableMember #Amount & #Date. 

In the script, VariableMember #Date table is utilized at lines 18‚Äì19 for Quantity and 25‚Äì26 for Amount, and VariableMember #Amount & #Date table is utilized at lines 22‚Äì23 for #Amount.

The two-row trace grid seems to contain records for #Amount & #Date, whereas the four-row trace grid appears to contain two Quantity value rows for #Date (lines 18‚Äì19) and two Amount value rows for #Date (lines 25‚Äì26). 

The temp table of #Date is structured as shown below, and the trace grid for lines 25‚Äì26 displays only the Amount column.

Please check the trace for the script lines 18~19,  and the Dimension members for the Quantity values are expected to correspond to those of the blank 2 records of Amount rows for line .

I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: SAP DRC e-invoicing and e-way bill - INDIA Localization
entry.content:
Document and reporting compliance enables the transformation of documents created in various SAP applications into predefined exchange formats and transfer them electronically to external systems, such as to the systems of legal or tax authorities. In India e-Documents can be created for the following document types:

  • Customer invoices created from billing or accounting documents
  • Invoice verification
  • Credit memos
  • Debit memos
  • Real estate invoices

The end-to-end process requires to use one of the supported GST Suvidha Providers (GSPs). For more information about third-party service providers check SAP Note 3556797

High Level View

In India mainly TWO tasks are associated with e-document

  • e-Way Bill - You can send invoices or delivery challans electronically to the government agency to obtain a valid e-waybill number which is needed before starting goods movement. As per the Goods and Service Tax (GST) law in India, a registered taxpayer, prior to movement of goods via a conveyance, needs to inform each transaction‚Äôs details to the tax department and generate an e-way bill for such movements. There are certain exemptions and exclusions from the requirement for e-way bills. Electronic Way Bill is a valid document accompanying the transport vehicle.
  • e-invoice - You can register invoices electronically with the Invoice Registration Portal to obtain the Invoice Registration Number (IRN) and it becomes a legally valid e-invoice.

Direct integration to e-Invoicing (IRN) system via GSP. This is a licensed solution developed by SAP which will provide direct integration between the SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA On-Prem systems or S/4HANA Cloud and the Government e-Invoicing platform via certified GSPs using the SAP Cloud Integration Platform. This will enable taxpayers to upload the payload from the backend SAP system to the e-Invoicing (IRN) portal, generate the Invoice Reference Number and link the Invoice Reference Number (IRN) with the billing document in the backend system.

FOUR Parameters to generate IRN

  • Supplier GSTIN
  • Supplier‚Äôs invoice number
  • Document Type (INV/CRN/DBN)
  • Financial year (YYYY-YY)

EIGHT Parameters to generate a QR Code

  • GSTIN of Supplier
  • GSTIN of Recipient
  • Invoice number as given by Supplier
  • Date of generation of invoice
  • Invoice value (taxable value and gross tax)
  • Number of line items
  • HSN Code of main item (the line item having highest taxable value)
  • Unique Invoice Reference Number (hash)

Key Statutory Reports (can be executed in Fiori)

  • GSTR1 Report - In India, the GSTR1 Report is a monthly return that should be filed by every registered businesses. It contains details of all outward supplies.
  • GSTR3B Report - GSTR3B is a monthly return to be filed by a registered GST taxpayer in India. It's a simplified return that consolidates the details of outward & inward supplies.
  • ITC04 Report - The form ITC04 is a declaration submitted by registered principals to report details of inputs and capital goods sent to or received from job workers during a specified tax period, in compliance with GST regulations. It stands for Input Tax Credit 04.
  • GSTR 6 Report - The GSTR 6 report provides you details of all the documents issued for distribution of input tax credit and the manner of distribution of credit and tax invoice on which credit is received.
  • Withholding Tax Reporting - Process invoice and payment documents posted within the reporting period and generate withholding tax report for submission to the tax authorities.

Pre Requisites

  • Licenses are obtained.
  • Business place setup to have GST Number
  • BP Master data equipped with IN3 (GST number) and IN2 (TIN No) Tax category.
  • For e-Invoicing as a prerequisite ODN number range should have been defined by Finance team
  • Material Master to have proper HSN/SAC codes.
  • Condition based Tax Procedure for India is already in place.
  • Tax Codes are available in system for country India.

Install and implement all the e-invoice relevant notes:

  • 3516531 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Prerequisite for SAP Note 3512964
  • 3512964 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Enabling the E-Invoice Solution for SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition
  • 3516185 - Electronic Document Processing for India - E-Invoice Solution Package Creation
  • 3479282 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Prerequisite for SAP Note 3516183
  • 3516183 - Electronic Document Processing for India - AIF Enabling the E-Invoice Solution
  • 3575681 - eDocument India: DCS Integration Issue
  • 3565298 - Electronic Document Processing for India: Automatic Status Update for Electronic Documents
  • 3586310 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Waybill - Error message appears when you cancel the eDocument
  • 3586081 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Waybill - Log not found while submitting the eDocument
  • 3584664 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Invoice- Log not found while cancelling e-invoice
  • 3599008 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Enabling the Error Analysis for Manage Electronic Documents App ( E-Invoice Solution)
  • 3580437 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Invoice - Correction for eDocument India eInvoice Enhancements BAdI
  • 3637865 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Invoice - Viewing Error Reasons in Application Log for E-Invoice

Configuration details ‚Äì E Way bills

Configuration details ‚Äì E invoice

Cancellation Process

e-Way cancellation:

  • If the goods were never transported or are not transported as per the details furnished in the Electronic Document (eDocument).
  • In such a scenario, you cancel the eWay bill. During cancelation you enter the valid reason for cancellation. For example, the goods are not being moved, incorrect entry in the eWay bill entered. Note that for this scenario, you do not cancel the eDocument.
  • To cancel only the eWay bill and not the eDocument, do not set the Cancel eDocument checkbox.
  • If you do not set the Cancel eDocument checkbox, the system cancels the eWay bill number generated by tax authority. In such a scenario, the eDocument is still available. If required later, you can generate the eWay bill for the eDocument
  • If you set the Cancel eDocument checkbox, the system cancels the eDocument. In such a scenario you will have to additionally cancel the source document.

e-Invoice cancellation:

According to govt, IRN cancellation can only happen within 24 hours of its generation. Any cancellation after 24hrs could not be possible on IRN, however one can manually cancel the same on the GST portal before filing the returns.

If the source document needs to be canceled in SAP post 24 hours of IRN generation:

  1. Perform the ‚ÄòCancel eDocument‚Äô action under ‚ÄòMore‚Äô in EDOC_COCKPIT and it should fail with the error ‚ÄúError Code 2270: The allowed cancellation time limit is crossed, you cannot cancel the IRN.‚Äù
  2. Use the ‚ÄòAllow Cancellation‚Äô action under ‚ÄòMore‚Äô in EDOC_COCKPIT to enable the cancellation of the source document. The status will be changed to ‚ÄòALLOW_CANCEL‚Äô to allow source document cancellation.

Note: This does not have any impact on IRP portal data and only allows to cancel source document in the SAP system. After canceling the source document, ensure to cancel the outward liability while filing GSTR1 returns.

Manual correction option:

In case the automated solution is being used for an e-Invoice generation but the e-Invoice got generated offline, later eDocument status can be updated using contingency mode. The contingency report J1IGIRN can be used to upload the IRN response file back to EDOC_COCKPIT.

Download the respective response JSON file from the IRP portal and upload it in the J1IGIRN transaction. The e-Document status will get updated and associates the IRN details in e-Document tables.

I will write more blogs on other countries DRC set up and details Enjoy reading

entry.title: Re: Integrated Financial Planning OPEX Cost Rates Data Ac...
entry.content:
Hi SANA11,

absolutely correct.

IF @Iteration = 0 THEN BREAK ENDIF controls that the iteration only is executed when the iteration parameter is set to 1.

The iteration stops after maximally 100 steps in order not to run infinitely if the iteration does not converge.

The Delta is calulated as the total cost center balance which should converge to zero. As you say this means Debit = Credit.
If Delta is small enough, the iteration stops.

Best regards
Hartmut

entry.title: Re: Ledger 0E is not a universal journal entry ledger Mes...
entry.content: Check in Financial Accounting (New) ‚Üí Financial Accounting Global Settings (New) ‚Üí Ledgers ‚Üí Define Ledger Groups. Identify any ledger group which shows 0E. If found, delete it from there. Next go to SSCUI Assign Ledger Group to Depreciation Area and ensure only universal journal ledgers are assigned. Remove any reference to 0E or legacy ledger groups. For any reasons, if ledger 0E was inherited from a legacy configuration or copied from another client, it may be cached in metadata. Cleaning the ledger group and reassigning it ensures SAP doesn‚Äôt reference it during validation.

entry.title: Evolving from Manual AI Deployment to Intelligent Operational Orchestration: A COO‚Äôs Viewpoint
entry.content:
Over the years, I have firsthand witnessed how organizations adopt new, advanced technologies. Some move forward with bold vision, while others take the next step cautiously, assessing the terrain with small, contained pilots. Artificial Intelligence is no exception. 

In the majority of boardrooms today, AI has undeniably become essential to business. Yet, it is often leveraged on a project-by-project basis ‚Äì an analytics dashboard, a predictive model, or a chatbot for any other department. These projects are strategic foundations but usually fail to achieve holistic transformation. 

The concern isn‚Äôt the AI itself. It‚Äôs how enterprises deploy it ‚Äì disconnected, incremental, and fragmented from an integrated business roadmap. The outcome? Teams functioning in isolation, information gets siloed, and tech leaders struggle to align AI investments towards tangible business results. 

This is why I believe we stand at an inflection point: the paradigm shifts from manual AI deployment to what I call intelligent operational orchestration. 

Beyond Disconnected Pilots 

Leveraging AI in an isolated fashion might lead to a false sense of advancement. A department might only see cost savings or efficiency gains, but the larger picture often remains the same. When insights fail to flow across different organizational departments, AI stays experimental rather than driving enterprise-wide transformation. 

To leap forward, organizations need to change their mindsets - AI is not a collection of standalone applications. It's the binding network of data with decisions, people with processes, linking strategy with execution, and modern operations. 

This highlights the path toward what I define as intelligent orchestration‚Äîa model where AI not only helps optimize tasks, but also orchestrates greater business outcomes. 

What Intelligent Operational Orchestration Actually Means 

At its heart, orchestration brings intelligence together across the enterprise. It advances beyond deploying more models or automation. Instead, it ensures that decision frameworks, processes, and data operate in unison. 

Think of this as migrating from a series of solo performances to a finely tuned symphony. The significant instruments - AI models, data pipelines, and automation workflows - are already present. Orchestration unites them, ensuring every component contributes efficiently at the right time to deliver exponential impact. 

In this context, orchestration helps enterprises to: 

  • Integrate intelligence into processes rather than considering it an extra. 
  • Allow cross-functional partnerships to break down silos where important information often stays confined. 
  • Align technology with strategy to ensure AI initiatives directly contribute to long-term goals. 

Orchestration: Significance and Relevance 

The timing could not have been more crucial. We live in a rapidly changing era, also defined by uncertainty like mounting competition, regulatory changes, shifting client behaviors, and supply chain disruptions. In such an ecosystem, organizations can‚Äôt rely on standalone improvements anymore; they require systemic agility. 

Intelligent operational orchestration helps with precisely the same. It delivers the most critical benefits enterprises should not overlook: 

  • Agility at Scale - Enterprises can respond rapidly to opportunities or disruptions because intelligence flows easily across functions and processes. 
  • Operational Efficiency - Orchestration helps eradicate duplicated efforts, redundant processes, and manual handoffs, which frees your employees to concentrate more on value-driven work. 
  • Future-Readiness - Because orchestration is flexible, organizations can upgrade their operating models without revamping from the start, every time the market changes. 

Data supports this! As per McKinsey‚Äôs research, organizations integrating AI across different workflows‚Äînot just in projects‚Äîillustrate 20‚Äì30% operational efficiency and solid market leverage. 

Lessons from the Field 

In my conversations with different global leaders, I‚Äôve spotted a repeating trend - scale drives results. 

  • As per some reports by Deloitte, AI-driven financial automation can decrease closing time by up to 40% and enhance forecast accuracy by 20%.   
  • A global food and beverage manufacturer also leveraged ThroughPut‚Äôs AI platform, which recovered $0.5M in weekly productivity losses and increased output by 5% through reduced unplanned downtime and smarter machine utilization. 

These two stories highlight one crucial fact - AI serves as a revolutionary technology only when orchestrated, not when implemented in isolation. 

From The COO‚Äôs Desk: Guiding Leadership Amid Orchestration 

As a COO, I regard orchestration as not just be treated as a technical challenge but a core leadership responsibility. Success with AI goes beyond experimentation; it's more about integrating intelligence rooted at the core of the operating model. 

For leaders, this means: 

  • Adopting an Ecosystem Mindset 
    AI use cases should not only be restricted to departmental barriers. Leaders should foster collective intelligence, where every process benefits from the shared insights. 
  • Aligning AI with Strategic Results 
    Orchestration must deliver outcomes beyond efficiency. It should solidify resilience, improve client value, and unlock innovation. 
  • Scaling with Intention 
    Expanding orchestration abilities needs governance models and systems that scale with the business. Short-term pilots should grow into long-lasting capabilities. 
  • Encouraging Cultural Readiness 
    Most significantly, orchestration thrives on cultural alignment. Teams need to learn to trust AI-based information, emphasize enterprise-wide results, and collaborate across silos. 

Looking Ahead 

In my view, the next great stride for organizations is more than just scaling AI‚Äîit‚Äôs all about orchestrating it smartly. 

This transformation highlights the next phase of enterprise growth. What once started as an experimental project is now entering its prime with company-wide orchestration frameworks that help drive scalability and resilience. 

Successful enterprises treat AI adoption not as a forward-thinking experiment, but as a coordinator of operations‚Äîa key driver of adaptability, agility, and strategic resilience. 

From my perception, as a COO, the ultimate proof of success is not how widespread AI is being leveraged, but how smartly it is orchestrated.

entry.title: Understanding CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks) in under 5 minutes
entry.content:
AI isn‚Äôt a dream of the future anymore; it‚Äôs all around us. With countless acronyms and concepts to grasp, one you can‚Äôt afford to ignore if you want to thrive at consulting is CNN, as it‚Äôs reshaping how companies operate and create value in digital economies. 

In this quick guide, we‚Äôll break down what CNNs are, why they matter, and how you can start building the skills to bring this knowledge into your consulting career. 

üëâRead through to the end for a resource that will help you take the first step in developing these skills. 

 
So, What is a CNN?  

A CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) is a type of deep brain network that takes hints from how we see. Inspired by the way human brains interpret visual signals, it spots lines, edges, shapes, and patterns. Unlike the ‚Äúold brain‚Äù webs that "see" each bit alone, CNNs can keep track of where things are. This helps them deal with big sets of pics, clips, etc.  

Why Convolutional? Well, the CNNs maintain spatial relationships by using layers called ‚Äúconvolutions‚Äù Read more here 

How does a CNN run? (In 3 steps) 

  • The ‚ÄúConvolutional Layer‚Äù has three components: the input, which is an image, a kernel (also known as a filter) to detect features like lines, edges, or colors; and an output, which is a feature map summarizing the features found.   
  • The ‚ÄúPooling Layer‚Äù: This layer simplifies the size of the feature map, keeping only the most important information.   
  • The ‚ÄúFully Connected‚Äù Layer takes all that information and uses it to perform classification or regression tasks

What is the difference between CNN and DNN?  

  • A DNN, Deep Neural Network, is an ‚ÄúAI brain web‚Äù with lots of links. It sees facts piece by piece, making it good for tasks like seeing pics, hearing speech, & dealing with words.  
  • CNN is a kind of specialized DNN, well-suited for handling image data. The key difference is the ability to apply filters to the input image to extract key features. The information extracted through these layers is then passed to ‚Äúfully connected layers,‚Äù which analyze the features and can generate predictions.   

 

 The big gap is what they do best: DNNs are all-around and work with many kinds of tasks. CNNs are top at jobs that need seeing & knowing visual facts.   

What are CNNs mainly used for

Tasks with Pics  

CNNs work well at sorting, classifying, and detecting objects in images. They have transformed how companies manage visual information: from predictive maintainance tasks in manufacturing to smart supply chain management.  

Dealing with Docs  

CNNs are widely used to automate the extraction of information from documents such as invoices, receipts, and contracts. Instead of relying on manual work or rigid rule-based systems, CNNs can identify and capture key data pointssuch as dates, monetary values, and vendor names with higher accuracy and speed. This also reduces human error, streamlines workflows, and ensures more reliable data for follow-up processes. 

Seeing Things Early  

As said, CNNs are great for looking at things. And they are the perfect ally in enterprise contexts to ‚Äúsee things early‚Äù. CNNs can help look at data coming from equipment and machinery, for instance, and detect patterns and anomalies that signal possible failures. This potentially cuts costs & keeps work smooth.  

CNNs in the SAP Ecosystem

The integration of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and other advanced AI technologies within SAP Business AI  is reshaping how businesses run and their competitiveness. 

This means clients will increasingly expect you to explain not only the technology, but also the business value it creates. By embedding artificial intelligence into foundational business systems, SAP enables enterprises to enhance operational efficiency, leverage data-driven insights, and drive sustained innovation. As the company continues to evolve its AI offerings, consultants who can connect these capabilities to business outcomes will be the ones helping organizations achieve long-term success in an increasingly competitive marketplace. 

üëâIf you want to kickstart your career in consulting, explore the SAP Young Professionals Program,  an initiative designed to upskill young talent in SAP‚Äôs latest solutions and prepare them as Associate Consultants, ready to deliver value across the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: How to use grouping in a sap.ui.table in SAPUI5
entry.content:
I need to use grouping in 'sap.ui.table.Table'. Even that 'enableGrouping' property is deprecated according to SDK Documentation, it seems to be still partially working. When pressing the column title, I can set the grouping needed, but it should be default, without need to click on it manually each time. How can fire the event of grouping from the controller?

Is there a different way to do this?

Using 'sap.m.Table' is not an option, one of the main reasons is because part of the requirements is to use Columns with multiLabels, filters and sorting.

Here is my test code.

 

<mvc:View controllerName="ns.project1.controller.View1" xmlns="sap.ui.table" xmlns:m="sap.m" xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc">
    <m:Page id="page" title="{i18n>title}">
       <Table
            enableGrouping="true" 
            groupBy="Name"
            rows="{Model>/ProductCollection}">
            <columns>
                <Column width="11rem" id="idMyColumn" sortProperty="Name" filterProperty="Name">
                    <m:Label text="Product Name" />
                    <template>
                        <m:Text text="{Model>Name}" wrapping="false" />
                    </template>
                </Column>
                <Column width="11rem">
                    <m:Label text="Product Id" />
                    <template>
                        <m:Input value="{Model>ProductId}"/>
                    </template>
                </Column>
            </columns>
        </Table>
    </m:Page>
</mvc:View>

entry.title: Re: COPC - Template Allocations for Planned Orders
entry.content: @KikoGurbindo Yes, template allocations from KP06 are integrated with the standard costing run. They are executed during cost center planning to distribute planned costs to recipient cost centers. The planned activity rates for these recipient cost centers (in KP26) then include these allocated costs. The standard costing run (CK11N/CK40N) uses these pre-calculated rates to value activities and does not execute templates itself. Template allocations are not used directly with planned orders

entry.title: HANA Predictive Integrator - Identifying it on the HANA DB
entry.content:
SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi) is a component of the SAP Predictive Analytics suite designed to seamlessly embed predictive capabilities into SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA. 

 What is SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi)?

SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi) allows SAP applications to:

  • Create and deploy predictive models tailored to specific business scenarios.
  • Embed predictive insights directly into business processes.
  • Manage the lifecycle of predictive models (e.g., retraining, debriefing) within the application itself.

SAP has been delivering the new Predictive content across many business areas out of the box using Pai from SAP S/4HANA On Premise 1709 and S/4HANA Cloud Edition 1705 and above.

PAi is delivered as a Delivery Unit to be installed on the HANA Database.

One can check if SAP Predictive Integrator is already installed on your system using the below SQL commands ‚Äì

Below command was executed using hdbsql  on Linux

Select DELIVERY_UNIT from ‚Äú_SYS_REPO‚Äù.‚ÄùDELIVERY_UNITS‚Äù;

Output -

The DELIVERY_UNIT ‚Äì HANA_UMML and HCP_PA_APL correspond to the SAP Predictive Integrator SAP Pai.

Once SAP Pai is already available on your SAP S/4 HANA system and while planning the release Upgrades, SAP Predictive Integrator is offered as a default selected component to be considered, as a part of the target stack by the Maintenance Planner along with SAP S/4HANA Server.

Unselecting the SAP Pai component in the MP initial selection screen, still adds up this component to the Stack Calculation of the target since PAi  is part of the source system.

Summary - 

SAP Predictive Integrator (PAi) - The PAi component seamlessly embeds predictive capabilities into SAP S/4 HANA. Since the PAi component is not delivered as an SAP Add-on, it cannot be found in the
SPAM transaction. PAi is delivered as a Delivery Unit installed on the HANA Database.
One way of identifying is by running SQL query on the HANA DB.

Can you please share your thoughts in the areas of PAi upgrade scenarios in the comments section, which will help us to get back to you and improve further.

entry.title: Re: Skip step in flexible PO workflow
entry.content:
Hi Henrike,

We chose option 1 since we didn't receive any additional updates.

Additionally, we want to know what is the importance of the action result "Restart Workflow" at Workflow step level. Workflow is automatically restarted when a PO (such as Approver1) is rejected from the MY Inbox app with the action result - Restart workflow. This implies that, with no changes to the PO, approver1 will receive the work item in their mailbox once more for approval.

As we don't want to send notifications to approver until the PO is changed, we wanted to control this automatic workflow restart. But in this instance, BADI-MMPUR_PO_WORKFLOW_RESTART is not triggered. It only starts when a modification is made to PO and saved.

We know that it functions when the workflow step "Restart workflow" is deleted. But we wanted to have the solution when the option is checked.

Looking for Some ideas/suggestions on this.

Thank you.

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: ABAP AI - Chapter 2
entry.content:
In February 2025, we started the first chapter of ABAP AI and announced that Joule speaks ABAP. Now, it‚Äôs time to get ready for chapter 2!

In the past months, we have been delivering more Joule skills to speed up ABAP Cloud development, and we are now able to create RAP business objects ‚Äì from the database table up to the UI service powered by generative AI. We can create unit tests, explain code, complete code in the editor, implement validations and determinations, and much more (see also our public slide deck). All these skills are part of the 2508 release of SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), and they will be included in the SAP Cloud ERP Private (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) in the 2025 release. Please check out our updated tutorial on ABAP AI capabilities. In addition, we will continue to expand our AI scope and will deliver on the transformation aspect of our AI strategy. This starts with the 2025 delivery for SAP Cloud ERP Private, followed by AI capabilities in the custom code migration app in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2602. Please visit our roadmap to keep track of our deliveries.

Let‚Äôs continue with commercials and keep it short: The free promotions we introduced at the beginning of the year have been extended until further notice! We are convinced that, in the current situation, we don‚Äôt want to put any commercial barriers on our offering and let all customers and partners benefit from AI-driven development. The corresponding material numbers for customers 8019124 and TDD partners 8019541 remain the same and can be ordered again. For those who started before the extension of the promotion, note that a re-ordering of the material is required. The procedure for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP remains the same as well, and the initial blog post has been updated to reflect this, as well as SAP Note 3571857.
For SAP Cloud ERP Private, as of release 2025, the material numbers are also valid. However, the configuration will need to be done manually by you. Detailed information on this will follow.

But that is not enough. Will ABAP AI capabilities become available also for older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private? Yes!
Imagine an ABAP AI service running side-by-side to your ABAP instance, providing full access to ABAP AI capabilities across hybrid landscapes. This includes SAP BTP ABAP Environment, SAP Cloud ERP, and SAP Cloud ERP Private. New AI innovations become available independently of release upgrades or support packages, allowing immediate leveraging.  Best of all, this ABAP AI service can also be connected to older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Sounds like a dream? Let‚Äôs find out ‚Äì stay tuned for TechEd 2025 to receive all the news and updates!

entry.title: SAP EWM MFS: Pallet conveyor Vs Case Conveyor systems
entry.content:
Hi All, I have been planning to pen down articles on one of the most interesting topics in SAP EWM, Which is the Material Flow systems. This will be the first of the series. Before we begin with, I'm assuming you have very basic idea on what SAP EWM MFS is.


SAP EWM Material Flow System (MFS) allows SAP EWM to communicate directly with programmable logic controllers (PLCs) that operate conveyor systems, automated storage and retrieval systems (ASRS), Cranes, AGVs and other material handling equipment through real-time telegram communication.

Fundamentally, MFS divides warehouse objectives/work by subdividing complex warehouse tasks into smaller segments that are executed step by step through automation. Going by the title of the Article, I‚Äôm assuming you already know the basics of MFS and would like to dig deep more into which strategy to use for your MFS implementation.

Pallet Conveyor systems and Case Conveyor systems: 

Under MFS, SAP offers different choice of implementations depending on various factors of your warehouse. Lets see what they are, in the simplest of terms:

Pallet Conveyor Systems

Pallet conveyor systems are generally to handle large, heavy palletized loads weighing between ~150-1000kgs. These systems operate at slower speeds due to their weight and size of the units being transported. However, We do see the same strategy being used for general MFS implementations.

Movements:
Using pallet conveyor systems, We divide the warehouse tasks using LOSC by defining the source and destination with an intermediate point. Warehouse tasks are created and confirmed for each movement that takes place and the same can be tracked on the warehouse monitor or any other cockpits; Same is the case with telegram data as well.

Generally, From what I have seen, Industries usually prefer for Pallet Conveyor system due to their clarity for each movements, which can be tracked back using warehouse tasks at each steps.

How does Pallet conveyor system differ from Case Conveyor systems?

 

Case Conveyor Systems

Case conveyor systems handle individual cases, boxes and totes weighing ~1-80 kgs per unit. These systems operate at significantly higher speeds and can process 300-1000 cases per hour, making them ideal for high-throughput sortation and distribution operations. We can imagine a highly automated warehouse with high throughputs.

Movements:

Case conveyor systems in EWM MFS offer dynamic routing decisions based on current location of the handling unit. Similar to pallet conveyor system, this set up reads the telegram data containing source and destination for the handling units and trigger the required movements.

This high speed nature of case conveyors requires quick telegram exchange between EWM and PLCs. In most cases, Case conveyor system only displays the warehouse task for source and destination for the HUs due to the complex and fast movements for the cases/boxes. Unlike Pallet conveyor systems, We would not have tracking for each movements for handling unit movements since the task creation and confirmation would consume time, which is not ideal for fast automation systems.

Since Case conveyor systems may need complex routing, they use internal routing table provided by SAP (which consists of logical source, destinations for EWM & PLC), In case the system fails to find the logical destinations for EWM/MFS maintained in the routine table, System falls back to LOSC to take the routing decisions. This is the standard behavior for Case Conveyor systems

What's best for your warehouse?

There are common factors for both the approaches- Both the systems are flexible with exception handling, routing decision making, integration of robots, Automatic guided vehicles etc.

What separates them?
As hinted above, Major differences are with the Operational Speed at which the pallet/boxes/totes move inside the warehouse.
Few other factors would include the scalability, Maintenance of slow/medium/fast moving systems, load types, How much track and traceability you require for your movements at each handling unit level.

Thanks,
Aman
